ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HDB RELOCATION PROGRAMME IN BOON TECK CONSTITUENCY


    1. Dr Ho Tat Kin asked the Minister for National Development what percentage of the rental tenants in Boon Teck Constituency have been relocated; whether the first phase relocation exercise is on schedule; when the land recovered under this exercise will be developed; and what will be the nature of the proposed development.

     The Minister of State for National Develpment (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, in Boon Teck Constituency, 10 blocks comprising 2,330 rental flats are affected by the current relocation programme. 1,185 flats were originally occupied when the relocation exercise commenced.

    By the beginning of March, the HDB had relocated 77% or 907 of the affected tenants. The remaining 278 tenants are being offered flats. Of the 278 remaining, 136 tenants are scheduled to be rehoused by the middle of 1988, whereas the other 142 are likely to be rehoused by the end of 1989. The relocation programme in Boon Teck is on schedule.

    The land vacated after the relocation exercise will be used for residential development. The first redevelopment project is scheduled to commence in early 1990. Depending on demand, better quality and bigger flat types are likely to be built in this area.

RECLAIMED LAND AT PULAU TEKONG BESAR
(Development plans)


    2. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development what are the development plans for the reclaimed land at Pulau Tekong Besar.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Sir, the reclaimed land at Pulau Tekong Besar is being used by the Ministry of Defence for training purposes. It will be used by MINDEF until

Column: 1496

such time as it is required for other developments. Possible uses in the long-term are industry, seaport and related development such as power station and utilities. It is not envisaged that there would be a need to put Pulau Tekong Besar to more intensive urban uses for some time. The future use of this island can therefore be further reviewed. Its future use would be the subject of further study by the Concept Plan Review Team.

COURTESY CAMPAIGN
(Effectiveness of)


    3. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Communications and Information (a) what is his Ministry's assessment of the effectiveness of the Courtesy Campaign; (b) whether Singaporeans have become more courteous after so many yea/rs of efforts in promoting the campaign; and (c) what is the future direction of the campaign.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and Information (Mr Ho Kah Leong) (for the Minister for Communications and Information): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    In December 1987, my Ministry engaged an independent research company to conduct a survey amongst a representative sample of 1,000 people. The folllowing questions were posed:

    (a) Do you personally think that Singaporeans are nowadays more courteous or less courteous?

    (b) If Singaporeans are more courteous, do you think they are more courteous because of the Courtesy Campaign or some other factors?

    (c) Do you think there is a need for Singapore to continue with the Courtesy Campaign in future years?

    (d) In your opinion, how much effort do you think Singaporeans put into being courteous?

Assessment of Effectiveness of Campaign

    70% or nearly 3 persons out of 4 feel that Singaporeans are today more courteous than they were before.

Column: 1497



    66% or 2 people out of 3 attribute the increase in the level of courtesy solely to the campaign; whilst most of the remainder (27%) feel that it is due both to the campaign and other factors.

Should campaign continue?

    Nearly 9 people in 10 of those surveyed, or 89%, feel that the campaign should continue to be promoted in future. This may be due to the perceived effectiveness of the campaign since a total of 93% attributed the improvement in Singaporeans' behaviour to the campaign, either solely or in combination with other factors.

    The need for the Courtesy Campaign to continue may also be due to the observation by a majority (78%) of the people that Singaporeans on their own do not put in a lot of effort in being courteous. Only 19%, or nearly 1 in 5, feel that Singaporeans are putting in a lot of effort.

    There is therefore still a need for the people to be continuously reminded to be courteous. My Ministry will endeavour this year to drive home the need for courtesy to begin with the individual.

Long-term future direction

    Since the inception of the campaign in 1979, we have emphasized the forms of courteous behaviour. In future years, the emphasis of the campaign will be on the development of the character of the young in order to make courtesy a natural component of our people's behaviour and life style.

    We will endeavour to increase public awareness of the importance of character building as well as the important roles which families, schools, communities and workplaces have to play.

    Sir, while we must strive to be more productive in order to be more competitive internationally, at the same time, we must also preserve our Asian traditions of courtesy and respect for one another. If courtesy becomes a part of the Singaporean's personality, then courteous behaviour will come naturally from every individual without the need for reminders or campaigns.

Column: 1498



    If Singaporeans are to be well mannered, socially disciplined, confident and cultured, if we are to have a good environment for our children to live in peace and harmony, if we are to have the respect of individuals for one another and for public properties, all of us must play our part in promoting courtesy.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, are these courtesy campaigns aimed more at civil servants who are serving the public or the workers in the private sector who are serving the tourists in particular?

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: Sir, these courtesy campaigns are aimed at all Singaporeans.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Chong Boon): Including the Opposition!

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta)( In Mandarin):Sir, since 1979, how much has been spent on courtesy campaigns? Secondly, for this year's campaign, what is the theme which will be directed at the Singapore people? Will it include how to take buffets in a more courteous manner?

     Mr Ho Kah Leong( In Mandarin):Sir, since 1979 until this year, our Ministry has spent $3.8 million in the promotion of courtesy campaigns.

    As regards the second question of the Member for Delta on whether in this year's campaign Singaporeans will be taught how to behave well at buffets, I would stress that the campaign covers a wider scope than that. We would like to drive home the message to the Singaporeans that we should at all times bear courtesy in mind. And Singaporeans should also be conscious of the social norm of behaviour at buffets or occasions like that. This kind of consciousness in courtesy and social etiquette should be spread by all civic organizations and all the schools so as to reach all social life more effectively.

NEW DRIVING LICENCE


    4. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the size of the driving licence will be reduced to that of a credit card; (b) whether it is necessary to have the photograph of the licensee shown on the driving licence; and

Column: 1499

(c) whether the driving licence's validity period will be extended from 3 years to 5 years.

     The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Traffic Police is studying the feasibility of introducing a new driving licence of credit card size. The inclusion of the licensee's photograph will be considered also.

    For operational reasons, the Traffic Police does not intend to extend the driving licence's validity to five years. Currently, a person may renew his licence for one year or three years. More than 80% of the 760,000 licences are renewed for one year.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok: Sir, when will this feasibility study be completed?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, as I said, the Traffic Police is studying this new driving licence. We have not decided on the date of implementation. But the study will be carried out expeditiously.

OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY IN INDUSTRIES
(Standard of)


    5. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Labour if he is satisfied with the standard of occupational health and safety in industries and whether the trend of industrial accidents in 1987 implies that attention needs to be focused on a particular industry.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the standard of occupational safety and health in Singapore is satisfactory as indicated by the statistics on industrial accidents and diseases.

    In 1987, the total number of accidents reported to the Department of Industrial Safety was 4,155, a 7.7% increase over the 1986 figure of 3,856. The increase was partly attributable to the pick-up in economic activities last year. On the whole, however, the trend remained a healthy one, with the number of accidents dropping by more than 30% over the last five years, from 6,045 accidents in 1983 to 4,155 last year.

Column: 1500



    The construction and the shipbuilding and repairing industries remained the two industries with the largest number of accidents. In 1987, these two industries combined accounted for 1,479 cases or about 35% of the total number of accidents. Hence, my Ministry will continue to focus its attention on the reduction of accidents in these two industries.

    In 1987, 1,073 cases of industrial diseases were confirmed. This represents a drop of 48% as compared to 2,068 cases for 1986. Since the introduction in 1985 of the compulsory medical examinations requirement, the bulk of the old cases has already been detected. Noise-induced deafness constitutes 70% of the cases. The noise problem is particularly prevalent in the metal-working factories and shipyards. The Department of Industrial Health will therefore continue to implement measures to control the problem, with particular attention on these two industries.

UNEMPLOYED DISABLED
(Assistance for)


    6. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for Community Development (a) whether figures are available on the number of the unemployed disabed in our society; (b) how the Government and non-governmental organizations can assist the disabled to find employment; and (c) whether there are schemes to provide skills training for them.

     The Minister for Community Development (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Sir, the Ministry does not have comprehensive figures on the extent of unemployment among the disabled people in Singapore.

    In 1985, my Ministry surveyed 4,385 disabled people aged between 16 and 55 years old. The results showed that 1,969 or 45% were employed, while 2,416 or 55% were unemployed. Of the 2,416 unemployed, 1,405 or 58% were unemployable. Of the remaining 1,011 disabled people, 531 of them were suited for open employment and 480 of them for sheltered employment.

    The assistance given by the Government and non-governmental organizations to

Column: 1501

help disabled people secure employment are:

(a) Open Employment

    Government helped the Singapore Council of Social Service to promote employment opportunities for disabled people through public awareness programmes; set up a Centralized Job Placement Service for disabled people; assist voluntary welfare organizations to upgrade their sheltered production workshops.

    The Government provided a building to house the Central Job Placement Service and a production sheltered workshop at a nominal rental. It also gave $38,000 to start up the centre and an annual operating grant of $44,500.

    In 1987, before the setting up of the Central Job Placement Service, 212 jobs were found for the disabled.

(b) Sheltered Employment

    The Singapore Council of Social Service's sheltered production workshop for disabled people should be ready in August 1988. Five voluntary welfare organizations already provide sheltered employment for 435 disabled people in assembly work, packing, pasting and book binding.

(c) Additonal Employment Outlets

    Since 1986, there is a scheme to allocate hawker licences and stalls to disabled people. 27 disabled people have obtained stalls through the scheme, but six have since given up their stalls.

    A pilot scheme will start later this month to allocate purpose-built sales counters at Esplanade, Amoy Street and Telok Ayer Food Centres for disabled people to sell sundry goods. HDB is also shortlisting 20 food centres to set up sales counters for disabled people. This scheme is expected to begin in June 1988.

(d) Skills training Scheme for Disabled People

    Two voluntary welfare organizations now provide formal training for disabled

Column: 1502

people who can be trained. The Singapore Association for the Deaf provides accredited training at NTC 3 level in dressmaking, furniture production and general welding for 112 hearing impaired people. The Society for Aid to the Paralysed provides pre-vocational training for physically disabled people in pre-press, offset printing and book binding. Five other voluntary organizations provide some form of informal on-the-job training for their respective clientele.

    One factor impeding disabled people in vocational training is the low literacy level. My Ministry, in conjunction with the VITB and the Skills Development Fund, has assisted the Society for Aid to the Paralysed and the Handicaps Welfare Association to set up BEST classes for their members. Since October 1985 134 disabled people have gone through the BEST classes.

    I have also set up a Vocational Training Co-ordinating Committee in October 1987 with members of the VITB, the Council for Social Service and the Voluntary Welfare Organizations to help identify, plan and implement appropriate skills training programmes for disabled people.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, in the Minister's answer I notice that he has not mentioned or identified any organization or bodies which help the blind. Perhaps he could enlighten us whether or not the Government has any organization set up or any voluntary organization set up to assist the blind?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, the blind formed themselves into the Singapore Association for the Visually Impaired and they have their own training schemes too. And we have given them assistance.

NATIONAL MANPOWER PLANNING


    7. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether the present national manpower planning and the various steps taken towards training and education are satisfactory and, if so, if he will elaborate on them.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Council for Professional and Technical Education (CPTE) is a ministerial com-

Column: 1503

mittee, chaired by the Minister for Trade and Industry, which is responsible for manpower planning in Singapore. It tries to ensure that the supply of manpower meets demand, and that our schools and institutions provide education and training which is relevant to the needs of our growing economy.

    Manpower planning is not an exact science. The planners must predict the state of the economy five to 10 years ahead, anticipate what jobs will be in demand, and guess the number of places needed which will be needed in each discipline. The uncertainties are large. But the alternative is to leave it to the individuals to make their own guesses, on the basis of even more incomplete information about the future, on which courses they wish to study, and hope that their choices and guesses turn out right. This is unlikely to be a superior solution.

    Each year, MTI reviews our manpower plans. It projects the number of graduates, technicians, and skilled workers which the economy requires, on the basis of GDP growth, change in economic structure, demand for different types of jobs in each sector of the economy and the supply of qualified students.

    MTI also monitors the number of students graduating from our institutions, how easily they have found jobs and how much they are paid. On this basis, CPTE sets enrolment targets for the various courses at the universities, the polytechnics and the VITB.

    Our manpower planning has succeeded in meeting the needs of the economy for trained personnel at all levels, and in training our students in disciplines in which they can readily find jobs. Although from time to time there have been shortages in particular disciplines, for example, electrical engineering, overall the planning has been reasonably accurate.

    Since 1980, CPTE projects have provided the basis for a massive expansion of technical and tertiary education in Singapore. If you look at the figures, for University intakes, 1980, it is 3,002. 1987, 5,114 or 70%. Polytechnics, 1980, 3,113, 1987, 7,550 or an increase of 2.4 times. The VITB, 1980 intakes, 5,311, 1987 intakes 9,403, an increase of 80%.

Column: 1504



    The major constraint on the expansion of technical education has been the number of qualified trainees, not the demand for graduates or the availability of places. The Minister for Education last week cited the example of the Engineering faculty at the University, which expanded rapidly, had difficulty in filling its places, and admitted some marginal students, and then suffered high failure rates in its five year examinations. The same hs happened with VITB. In 1987, last year, VITB offered more than 13,000 places for skills training. Only 8,000 were taken up. Similarly at polytechnics, even last year, courses like Mechancial Engineering, by no means a discipline in the doldrums, had places still unfilled.

    The supply of qualified students will continue to be the major constraint on our output of skilled manpower. The more qualified students we have, the more trained personnel we can produce and the more our economy can expand, provided academic standards are maintained, and the students are trained in the right disciplines.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, I note that the MTI's study of manpower needs of Singapore is related only to the economy at all levels, as the Minister has said. But does this also include professions like teachers and nurses? There seems to be a shortfall in these two areas.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, teachers and nurses are part of the economy. So when we consider the needs of the economy, they are also calculated in.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Would the Minister be able to make available the information on manpower needs from time to time to people who are their planning careers ahead? Would he expect this information to be made available this year, or when will be the nearest date possible for such information to be made available?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Yes, MTI is looking for ways to provide more information on the manpower needs of the economy, who disciplines need people, which faculties produce graduates who are in the greatest demand and are employed most quickly, so that students can know and make informed choices. We are working

Column: 1505

on it. We should be able to release something this year.

    The biggest misallocation in our tertiary education is the very low proportion of girls doing Engineering. 90% of the Engineering Faculty are boys. We are very short of able students to do Engineering. Yet the girls who, at 'A' levels do as well as the boys if not better, are simply not choosing that subject. They go into subjects like Accountancy, Business Administration. They have very good grades, much higher than the grades which would admit them into the Engineering Faculty. In fact, if we look at the job market the demand for Accountancy or Business Administration graduates is lower than the demand for Engineers. The starting salary of an electrical engineer is at $2,000, of an Accountant perhaps $1,000. But there is a strong cultural bias. Girls do not do Engineering because they think they may get your hands dirty. But in electrical engineering, you do not get your hands dirty. That has not sunk in. If we can shift that bias, we will have a more optimal allocation of University undergraduates.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Would the Minister make available information on the starting wages and salaries for the different categories of skills on a regular basis, as this would be an additional useful indicator for students to choose the type of careers?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Yes, we will do that. In fact, there are already some statistics. I released some last year at a talk in NTI and the students copied down assiduously every single figure as if I was giving them a lecture. We will do it regularly. I hope it will be additional input into their choice. But I also hope that undergraduates do not only choose subjects on the basis of their starting salary. You have to plan a career and it must be a satisfying one. If you are shortsighted and money-minded, you will end up very sad.

SCHOOL DENTAL SERVICE
(Extension to secondary schools and junior colleges)


    8. Dr Ho Tat Kin asked the Acting Minister for Health how successful is the

Column: 1506

School Dental Service; and whether this service will be extended to secondary schools and junior colleges.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, the School Dental Service provides a comprehensive dental health programme for about 95% of the primary school population through dental clinics located in the primary schools. When the School Dental Service first started in 1948, dental caries was rampant. Many teeth could not be saved and had to be extracted. With the introduction of water fluoridation and a succesful school dental health programme, the dental health of our children has improved considerably. The average number of Decayed, Missing and Filled teeth, or the DMF(T), index of our 12-year old children has decreased from six in 1958 to 2.5 in 1984. Our DMF(T) index is about one of the lowest in the world and compares very well with that of the developed countries. For example, Japan's DMF(T) index is 5.9, UK 3.1 and USA 2.6. Singapore, as I said, have a DMF(T) of 2.5 The School Dental Health programme has been extended to about 50% of secondary school students who make use of nearby primary school dental clinics.

    Sir, my Ministry does not intend to build any dental clinics in secondary schools and junior colleges. Secondary school and junior college students will be encouraged to use existing school dental clinics and the dental centres at the Institute of Dental Health and the Pegu Road which provide free dental service for school children.

    My Ministry will conduct dental screening for all secondary three children annually from this year onwards. Advice on their dental condition and treatment needs as well as reinforcement of their knowledge of dental health will be given.

BLOOD BANK
(Blood contamination and causes)


    9. Dr Ho Tat Kin asked the Acting Minister for Health what percentage of blood collected by the Blood Bank in 1986 and 1987 could not be used because of contamination; what were the main causes of the contamination; whether the percentage has been on the increase; and

Column: 1507

what does his Ministry do with the contaminated blood.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the percentage of blood collected by the Blood Bank in 1986 and 1987 that was contaminated and could not be used, was 2.3% and 2% respectively.

    The main causes of the contamination were Hepatitis B virus and syphilis.

    The level of contamination has been fairly stable, fluctuating around the 2% mark.

    The contaminated blood is sterilized in an autoclave to destroy all bacteria and viruses and then disposed through the sewer.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin (Boon Teck): Sir, are those who donate contaminated blood notified by the Ministry for follow-up treatment?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Yes. Those with either Hepatitis B or syphilis are informed that their blood is contaminated and they are advised to either go to their family doctor or seek treatment at our Middle Road Clinic.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, is there a possibility of receivers getting contaminated blood?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, our blood supply is one of the safest in the world, if not, the safest. We take great care to analyse all blood donations to ensure that the blood that is being transfused is free from contaminants.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Sir, when we adjourned on Friday, the Member for Chua Chu Kang was asking me why I did not call a rose a rose, why we were revising JTC rental rates upwards and, particularly, whether we have taken into consideration the difficulties which are faced by the plywood and woodworking industries the sawmills at Kranji, which were not doing well. Of all people, I would have thought I would have the least reputation for reluctance to call a rose a rose. Let me state the facts as they are.

    When the recession hit us in 1985, we gave a special 25% discount on JTC rental rates. We recognized that the property market had fallen, rentals of commercial property had gone down, and factories were in difficulty. It was right to make a 25% discount for a limited period of time, initially one year. After one year, because the economy had not fully recovered, we extended the rebate for another year. The rebate ended on 31st December 1987. The question was: what should we do? We could have done nothing and simply let it lapse. That would have put us back to the status quo as it was in 1985. We decided not to do this because we recognize that even today, although the recession is over, rental rates are still generally lower than they were at the peak of the property boom in 1983 and 1984.

    As a result, we made a special effort to review all the market rents declared by JTC, to make sure that they were realistic and did not reflect a boom which had past. As a result of this revision, the market rentals declared by JTC for its properties were revised downwards by anything from 13% to 25% depending on the location, and the type of factory building. Thus when the discount lapsed, instead of factories just paying 25% more, the increase was much less depending on location. I think that is a reasonable approach.

    To confirm that, we compared our rates with the private sector. There are private sector industrial properties, although not many. Our rates are marginally higher, which is right, because JTC factories are, generally speaking, better managed, have better facilities and are in much higher demand. In fact, the question was asked on Friday what the occupancy rate of

Column: 1509

flatted factories is, and it is more than 92%. In other words, it is time for us to build many more now, otherwise we will have a shortage in the foreseeable future. That is what we have done with the factory rates.

    At the same time we have reviewed our land rental rates. Some land rentals have been reduced in unpopular locations. Indeed some lessees, despite this, have had their rentals revised up. The reason is they were paying rentals which were frozen long before the previous property boom, in fact, over the last 10-15 years, their rentals have not been revised to reflect market conditions, and are a fraction of the market rate today, even allowing for the drop since 1984.
